trans-unit.source: Working with Custom Domains in Azure AD Application Proxy
trans-unit.target: Working with Custom Domains in Azure AD Application Proxy

trans-unit.source: Covers how work with custom domains in Azure AD Application Proxy.
trans-unit.target: Covers how work with custom domains in Azure AD Application Proxy.

trans-unit.source: Working with custom domains in Azure AD Application Proxy
trans-unit.target: Working with custom domains in Azure AD Application Proxy

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Application Proxy is a feature that is available only if you upgraded to the Premium or Basic edition of Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Application Proxy is a feature that is available only if you upgraded to the Premium or Basic edition of Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Azure Active Directory editions](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn532272.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Azure Active Directory editions](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn532272.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Using a default domain enables you to set the same URL as the internal and external URL for accessing the application so that your users only have one URL to remember to access the app, no matter where they are accessing from, and it enables you to create a single shortcut in the Access Panel for the application.
trans-unit.target: Using a default domain enables you to set the same URL as the internal and external URL for accessing the application so that your users only have one URL to remember to access the app, no matter where they are accessing from, and it enables you to create a single shortcut in the Access Panel for the application.

trans-unit.source: If you use the default domain provided by Azure AD Application Proxy, there’s no additional configuration you need to enable your domain.
trans-unit.target: If you use the default domain provided by Azure AD Application Proxy, there’s no additional configuration you need to enable your domain.

trans-unit.source: In the event that you use a custom domain, there are a few things you need to do to make sure that Application Proxy recognizes your domain and validates its certificates.
trans-unit.target: In the event that you use a custom domain, there are a few things you need to do to make sure that Application Proxy recognizes your domain and validates its certificates.

trans-unit.source: Selecting your custom domain
trans-unit.target: Selecting your custom domain

trans-unit.source: Publish your application according to the instructions in Publish applications with Application Proxy.
trans-unit.target: Publish your application according to the instructions in Publish applications with Application Proxy.

trans-unit.source: After the application appears in the list of applications, select it and click **Configure**.
trans-unit.target: After the application appears in the list of applications, select it and click **Configure**.

trans-unit.source: Under **External URL**, enter your custom domain.
trans-unit.target: Under **External URL**, enter your custom domain.

trans-unit.source: If your external URL is https, you will be prompted to upload a certificate so that Azure can validate the URL of the application.
trans-unit.target: If your external URL is https, you will be prompted to upload a certificate so that Azure can validate the URL of the application.

trans-unit.source: You can also upload a wildcard certificate that matches the External URL of the application.
trans-unit.target: You can also upload a wildcard certificate that matches the External URL of the application.

trans-unit.source: This domain must be within the list of your [Azure verified domains](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/jj151788.aspx).
trans-unit.target: This domain must be within the list of your [Azure verified domains](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/jj151788.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Azure must have a certificate for the domain URL of the application or a wildcard certificate that matches the External URL for the application.
trans-unit.target: Azure must have a certificate for the domain URL of the application or a wildcard certificate that matches the External URL for the application.

trans-unit.source: Make sure to add a DNS record that routes the internal URL to the application that enables you to have the same URL for internal and external access and a single shortcut to the application in the user’s applications list.
trans-unit.target: Make sure to add a DNS record that routes the internal URL to the application that enables you to have the same URL for internal and external access and a single shortcut to the application in the user’s applications list.

trans-unit.source: Frequently asked questions about working with custom domains
trans-unit.target: Frequently asked questions about working with custom domains

trans-unit.source: Q: Can I select an already-uploaded certificate without uploading it again?
trans-unit.target: Q: Can I select an already-uploaded certificate without uploading it again?

trans-unit.source: A: Previously uploaded certificates are automatically bound to an application, and there is exactly one certificate matching the application’s host name.
trans-unit.target: A: Previously uploaded certificates are automatically bound to an application, and there is exactly one certificate matching the application’s host name.

trans-unit.source: Q: How do I add a certificate and what format should the exported certificate be uploaded in?
trans-unit.target: Q: How do I add a certificate and what format should the exported certificate be uploaded in?

trans-unit.source: A: The certificate should then be uploaded from the application configuration page.
trans-unit.target: A: The certificate should then be uploaded from the application configuration page.

trans-unit.source: The certificate should be a PFX file.
trans-unit.target: The certificate should be a PFX file.

trans-unit.source: Q: Can ECC certs be used?
trans-unit.target: Q: Can ECC certs be used?

trans-unit.source: A: There is no explicit limitation on signature methods.
trans-unit.target: A: There is no explicit limitation on signature methods.

trans-unit.source: Q: Can SAN certs be used?
trans-unit.target: Q: Can SAN certs be used?

trans-unit.source: A: Yes.
trans-unit.target: A: Yes.

trans-unit.source: Q: Can wildcard certs be used?
trans-unit.target: Q: Can wildcard certs be used?

trans-unit.source: A: Yes.
trans-unit.target: A: Yes.

trans-unit.source: Q: Can a different certificate be used on each application?
trans-unit.target: Q: Can a different certificate be used on each application?

trans-unit.source: A: Yes, unless the two applications share the same external host.
trans-unit.target: A: Yes, unless the two applications share the same external host.

trans-unit.source: Q: If I register a new domain, can I use that domain?
trans-unit.target: Q: If I register a new domain, can I use that domain?

trans-unit.source: A: Yes, the list of domains is fed from is the tenant’s verified domain list.
trans-unit.target: A: Yes, the list of domains is fed from is the tenant’s verified domain list.

trans-unit.source: Q: What happens when a cert expires ?
trans-unit.target: Q: What happens when a cert expires ?

trans-unit.source: A: You will get a warning in the certificate section in the application configuration page.
trans-unit.target: A: You will get a warning in the certificate section in the application configuration page.

trans-unit.source: When a user tries to access the application, a security warning will pop up.
trans-unit.target: When a user tries to access the application, a security warning will pop up.

trans-unit.source: Q: What should I do if I want to replace a cert for a given app ?
trans-unit.target: Q: What should I do if I want to replace a cert for a given app ?

trans-unit.source: A: Upload a new certificate from the application configuration page
trans-unit.target: A: Upload a new certificate from the application configuration page

trans-unit.source: Q: Can I delete a cert and replace it?
trans-unit.target: Q: Can I delete a cert and replace it?

trans-unit.source: A: When you upload a new certificate, if the old certificate is not in use by another application, it will be automatically deleted
trans-unit.target: A: When you upload a new certificate, if the old certificate is not in use by another application, it will be automatically deleted

trans-unit.source: Q: What happens when a cert is revoked
trans-unit.target: Q: What happens when a cert is revoked

trans-unit.source: A: Revocation checks are not performed for certificates.
trans-unit.target: A: Revocation checks are not performed for certificates.

trans-unit.source: When a user tries to access the application, depending on the browser, a security warning might appear.
trans-unit.target: When a user tries to access the application, depending on the browser, a security warning might appear.

trans-unit.source: Q: Can I use a self-signed certificate?
trans-unit.target: Q: Can I use a self-signed certificate?

trans-unit.source: A: Yes, self-signed certificates are allowed.
trans-unit.target: A: Yes, self-signed certificates are allowed.

trans-unit.source: Note that if you’re using a private certificate authority, the CDP (certificate revocation point distribution point) for the certificate should be public.
trans-unit.target: Note that if you’re using a private certificate authority, the CDP (certificate revocation point distribution point) for the certificate should be public.

trans-unit.source: Q: Is there a place to see all the certificates for my tenant?
trans-unit.target: Q: Is there a place to see all the certificates for my tenant?

trans-unit.source: A: This is not supported in the current version.
trans-unit.target: A: This is not supported in the current version.

trans-unit.target: Sign up for Azure as an organization
